abstract: As Bank of America and the insurer MBIA continue to battle over claims left over from the financial crisis, the lawyers are doing well, but those who suffered in the crisis are not.
snippet: As Bank of America and the insurer MBIA continue to battle over claims left over from the financial crisis, the lawyers are doing well, but those who suffered in the crisis are not.
lead_paragraph: Two villains in the financial crisis — whose negligence, or worse, caused untold suffering when the property bubble burst — are fighting it out. They are battling in the courts, and now in the bond market, where lucky owners of one bond issued by a company that may yet go broke are being offered the chance to cash out at par value. Lawyers are cleaning up.The only people who don’t seem to be doing very well are those who are most deserving: the victims of the crisis.

headline.main: As the Crisis Is Revisited, Lawyers Win
headline.print_headline: As the Crisis Is Revisited, Lawyers Win

abstract: In recent weeks, money managers have been readily buying the new bonds of the region’s financial institutions, deals that just months ago would have seemed unlikely.
snippet: In recent weeks, money managers have been readily buying the new bonds of the region’s financial institutions, deals that just months ago would have seemed unlikely.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European bank debt, once an investment pariah, is suddenly popular.

headline.main: In a Switch, Investors Are Buying European Bank Bonds
headline.print_headline: European Bank Debt Is, Surprisingly, Selling
